channel.title: Ais on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content in Ais on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: Artist Rebecca Moss aboard the Hanjin Geneva
item.description:
Hanjin Shipping is a Korean container shipping firm that has gone into bankruptcy, disrupting the worldwide container network. About 8 percent of transpacific cargo goes through this carrier, and as of this writing the ships are in an uncertain legal status, subject to seizure by creditors at ports if they land with their cargo.

“Hanjin’s bankruptcy is the largest ever to hit the shipping industry so there’s no roadmap as to what will happen now, no precedent of comparable scale.” - BBC News

Rebecca Moss is aboard the Haijin Geneva, which is off the coast of Japan, awaiting orders. She signed up for a 23 day artist’s residency aboard the ship and then abruptly discovered that her cruise would not be quite what she expected.

It’s difficult to follow all of the details of Haijin, and the situation is fluid, changing from day to day. Here are some resources that capture the current situation.

Rebecca Moss’s odyssey is being chronicled by Kevin C. Griffin of the Vancouver Sun. British artist on Vancouver residency stranded on Hanjin freighter from September 1, 2016; ART SEEN: Stranded at sea, British artist sees her surroundings with new eyes from September 2, 2016. Kimberly Phillips, the curator/director at Access Gallery, is in touch with Rebecca by email.

The Hanjin Geneva is tracked in global waters via a system known as AIS. Follow its location through these services:

  • Vessel Finder
  • Marine Traffic
  • Marine Traffic photos
  • Fleetmon
  • Ship Spotting

A snapshot taken September 6 placed the ship off the cost of Chiba, Japan.

Some good sources for news on Hanjin Shipping:

  • JOC.COM has a section; subscription required
  • Lloyd’s List subscription required
  • Reuters: Hanjin Shipping
  • Wall Street Journal: Asian Business News
  • BBC News

As always Twitter is going to move faster for news than most other news sources; the hashtag #hanjin or #hanjinshipping is worth watching.
